title: raab hong kong
story: The Foreign Secretary Dominic Raab confirmed this afternoon that the UK will change the rules on extraditions to China as relations reached boiling point.Addressing the Commons, Mr Raab accused China of a serious violation and announced a series of hardline new measures.He said: Given the role China has now assumed for the internal security of Hong Kong, and the authority it is exerting over law enforcement, the UK will extend the arms embargo we have applied to mainland China.The Government has decided to suspend the extradition treaty immediately and indefinitely.We will not consider reactivating those measures unless there are clear and robust safeguards which are able to prevent extradition from the UK being misused under the new national security legislation.I will just say this the UK is watching and the whole world is watching.Mr Raab insisted Britain wants a positive relationship with China, but warned that it was not willing to look the other way.He said: As we strive for that positive relationship we are also clear sighted about the challenges ahead.We will always protect our vital interests, Including sensitive infrastructure, and we won’t accept any investment that compromises our domestic or national security.We will be clear where we disagree, and have been clear about the grave concerns regarding the gross human rights abuses being perpetrated against the Uighur Muslims in Xinjiang.It is precisely because we acknowledge chinas role in the world that we expect China to live up to its responsibilities.The announcement came just hours after Boris tore into the Communist state, saying those in Hong Kong had a right to protest.But the PM warned he was not going to be pushed into a position of being a knee-jerk sinophobe on every issue to do with China. He added: What we wont do is completely abandon our relationship with China, China is going to be a giant factor in our geopolitics, weve got to have a calibrated response. Were going to be tough on some things but also continue to engageon others. The move follows the US, Australia and Canada scrapping extradition agreements to Hong Kong.It comes as tensions between the UK and China escalated after the Government banned Huawei - the Chinese Communist party owned telecoms giant - from the G network in Britain. This included suspending Britains extradition to Hong Kong after national security laws meant those sent back could be hauled in front of Chinese courts and jailed in China. The Government claims the change violated the Sino-British Joint Declaration.The declaration was supposed to guarantee Hong Kong freedom from Chinese rule under the one county, two systems model for  years after the handover of the former British colony in .The law prohibits what Beijing views as secessionist, subversive or terrorist activities or as foreign intervention in Hong Kong affairs.Pro-democracy leader Nathan Law fled to the UK after the law came into effect this month. He told The Sunday Times he was afraid he may never be allowed to go back to Hong Kong. A -year-old girl waving a pro-democracy flag in Hong Kong on the day the law came into effect was among  people arrested under the legislation. The law grants police massive powers to conduct searches without warrants and order internet service providers and s to remove messages deemed to be anti-China. The Government has already taken strong action, offering three million Hongkongers eligible for a British Nationalpassport a path to UK citizenship. The Chinese ambassador to the UK Liu Xiaoming warned Britain not to enter into a tit-for-tat confrontation or follow the US in its sanctions on Chinese officials over alleged human rights abuses of Uighur muslims in Xinjiang. The law will criminalise any act of subversion, terrorism or collusion with foreign forces.The heaviest penalty that can be imposed is le in jail, the editor in chief of the Global Times newspaper claimed after citing those who have seen the draft of the law.Under the law, damaging public transport can be considered terrorism and those found guilty will be banned from standing for public office.Some trials will not be held in public while iniduals can be wire-tapped and put under surveillancethey are suspected of criminality.Beijing is also set to establish a security office in Hong Kong with its own law enforcement personnel and with the power to send some cases to mainland China to be tried.Beijing will further have power over how the law should be interpreted and Hong Kong will have to establish its own national security commission to enforce the laws, with a Beijing-appointed adviser.Mr Raab played down suggestions sanctions against officials could be brought in under the UKs new human rights scheme which can impose tough restrictions on abusers - including travel bans. He insisted that Britain wanted a positive relationship with China. Chair of the defence select commit Tobias Ellwood called for a reset of our entire foreign policy to fight back against Chinese aggression. He told BBC Radio s Westminster Hour programme that Britain had been duped over the couple of decades by China and needed to hit back with a firm hand. He said: “I really want to see a reset of our entire foreign policy, bearing in mind that we are sliding towards a cold war, we can’t do this on our own, we need to work with our allies.”“We turned a blind eye to what was going on with the Uighur population, we turned a blind eye to the uneven trade situation whereby Chinese companies could operate quite liberally within the UK and where but our companies couldn’t operate within China and now I think it’s time to say enough is enough.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: Police were called to an industrial estate in Tameside, Greater Manchester, yesterday after hundreds brought their cars to a site just outside the M.Shocking images and video show dozens of cars being lined up and a worrying lack of facemasks and social distancing among those present. title: banksy map britain art location uk
story: That even includes his most recent creation on the London Underground, which was wiped away despite being worth an estimated £.million – but thankfully many have survived. The mysterious Bristolian, whose works have sold for as much as £.million at auction, has also been working from home during lockdown. He shared pictures of nine of his trademark rats scurrying around his bathroom with the caption: My we hates it when I work from home. Butyou want to go and see some of his works in Britain, there are some around the country which have been preserved. The Love Plane first appeared on the Western Approaches on Rumford Street in Liverpool in , but it was then removed in  to be featured in a street art museum. When the museum never materialised, the beloved biplane painting was ed to the city centre in February  with the addition of a tag reading: Im back. This work, also known as Naked Man Hanging from Window, appeared on the side of a sexual health clinic in Banksys hometown in . It became the first legal street art in the UK after  per cent of respondents to a council poll said they wanted the lewd mural to stay.But despite efforts to protect the work, its been defaced by paintballs and black spray paint tags reading F**k Banksy. The Mild Mild West, showing a Molotov cocktail-wielding teddy bear, was painted in broad daylight over three days in . Locals have praised the graffiti on Stokes Croft, which was made in protest of police efforts to close down raves in the area in the s. Banksys cheeky take on the famous Vermeer painting, The Girl with the Pearl Earring, appeared in Hanover Place in . The mural was in the news again when a giant face mask appeared on the painting in April . Not far from Mild Mild West, Rose Trap can be found on Thomas Street North in Bristol.Locals put a plexiglass covering over the early Banksy mural keeping it safe for posterity. This work is the newest confirmed Banksy work in Bristol, appearing overnight on th February . Within hours of its discovery on Marsh Lane, vandals sprayed foul-mouthed messages over the top of it, prompting the owners of the house it appeared on to cover it up for protection. Banksys dystopian theme park, Dismaland, opened in a crumbling leisure centre on the Weston-super-Mare seafront in . Banksy gted its giant pinwheel to the town as a thank you for putting on the show, which welcomed over , visitors during its five-week run. Now the pinwheel is going to be displayed in the town centre – though as exactly when it will appear is not yet certain as work on its placement has been delayed during the pandemic, according to reports.Banksy gted Game Changer to Southampton General Hospital where for display until its auctioned off to raise money for the NHS this autumn. Its currently on display in the hospitals foyer near the emergency department, but is expected to fetch over £million when it goes under the hammer. In a note to hospital staff, Banksy wrote: Thanks for all youre doing. I hope this brightens the place up a bit, evenits only black and white.Banksys reindeer mural appeared in Birminghams Jewellery Quarter in December . A protective screen was put up in front of the painting after red noses were painted on to the original. Draw the Raised Bridge appeared on the disused Scott Street Bridge over the River Hull in January .A two-year plan has been drawn up to demolish the bridge and put the artwork onto a replacement, replica bridge. The Christmas themed Seasons Greetings mural was sprayed onto the side of a steelworkers garage in Port Talbot in December . Although its been sold to a gallery owner, it was agreed that the .tonne work would stay in the town for three years. Banksy stencilled the white words This is Not a Photo Opportunity on a clf face  metres up in Cheddar Gorge, Somerset, around . The work, near Clf Road, is said to still be slightly visible after years of exposure to the elements. This  mural appeared on the back of a staircase leading down to the beach in St. Leonards-on-Sea, East Sussex. Banksy has used Tesco branding in several dferent artworks over the years, including on a picture of a petrol bomb in . Banksys humourous Designated Graffiti Area is located in the courtyard of the nightclub Cargo on Rivington Street in Hackney. Another of his works showing a dog with a bazooka called His Masters Voice is in the same place. Banksys cartoon version of the Royal Family appeared in Stoke Newington as far back as . Its still visible from Stoke Newington Church Street, despite many attempts to paint over it over the years. The Extinction Rebellion mural appeared near Marble Arch in April  after the protest groups camp on the site was cleared. A message on the painting reads: From This Moment Despair Ends And Tactics Begin”.The mural of a police officer snorting cocaine first appeared on the side of a public toilet on Curtain Road in Hackney in . Its now inside an office building on the same road, but remains visible to the public through a viewing window. This mural appears on the side of a building on Bruton Street in Mayfair in November .Its anti-consumerist message, which Banksy uses in lots of his work, was undoubtedly chosen for its affluent surroundings. Two murals appeared by the Barbican in  during an exhibition of Basquiats work. Basquiat is a famous American street artist to whom Banksy was paying tribute. Writing on Instagram, he said: Major new Basquiat show opens at the Barbican – a place that is normally very keen to clean any graffiti from its walls.”Banksys most iconic symbol is the rat, and many of them are still dotted around London.One of the best examples can be found in an underpass connecting London Bridge with Tooley Street. title: boris not 100 percent confident vaccine
story: The PM said he hopes the weight of scientic effort racing to find a jab will triumph - but that Britain could have to rely on social distancing to drive the deadly virus out of the nation. ⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesMr Johnson said at a visit to a school in Kent this morning: I wish I could say I was  per cent confident we would get a vaccine by the end of the year. Im hopeful, Ive got my fingers crossed but to say Im  per cent confident we will get a vaccine this year or indeed next year is alas just an exaggeration.If you talk to scientists they thing the sheer weight of international effort is behind us. But weve got to continue with the current approach maintaining social distancing, weve got to do all the sensible things like washing hands and wearing face masks in confined spaces... and we will continue to drive down the virus.It may be that the vaccine is going to come riding over the hill like the cavalry but we just cant count on it right now.The UK has secured  million doses of a potential vaccine to make sure Brits are first in lineone of the hundreds of projects comes off. A spokesman for the PM said this lunchtime: A safe and effective vaccine is our best hope of defeating the virus and ing to normal – it will save millions of lives around the world and bring the pandemic to an end.Hopes of a cure soared today as Britains leading vaccination project at Oxford University published results for its first set of trials today showing it produced an immune response and was safe to be used. Health Secretary Matt Hancock told the House of Commons that the best solution to coronavirus over the long term was a vaccine. He said: I am delighted to say that Britain continues to lead the world. Two of the leading vaccines developments are taking place here at Oxford University and Imperial College London. He said the results from the Oxford trial were very encouraging. He told MPs: The UK is not just developing world leading vaccines but also putting more money into the global hunt for a vaccine - whoevers vaccine is approved first so the whole world can have access. He stressed that there was no place for nationalistic countries who would keep the vaccine for themselves in a fight against a virus which does not respect borders. title: prince philip rare public appearance
story: The -year-old royal, who has been isolating in Windsor since March , will step out of his retirement on Wednesday - almost three years after he bowed out of public office.The Duke of Edinburgh will transfer his role as Colonel-in-Chief of The Rles to Camilla, Duchess of Cornwall across two ceremonies.The engagements will take social distancing measures into account and the Duke will not come into close contact with Camilla, .Buckingham Palace confirmed the first of the ceremonies will take place in Windsor Castle, where the Duke has been isolating since March.The other will be held shortly after at Highgrove House, where the Duchess is currently living.In a statement, the Palace said: The ceremony will begin at Windsor Castle where four Buglers, of The Band and Bugles of The Rles, will sound The Rles Assembly call upon the arrival of the Duke of Edinburgh.The ceremony will continue at Highgrove House, where the arrival of the Duchess of Cornwall will be marked by four Buglers of The Band and Bugles of The Rles sounding The Rles Assembly. Her Royal Highness will be addressed by The Rles Colonel Commandant, General Sir Patrick Sanders, who will welcome The Duchess as the new Colonel-in-Chief.The Prince will be praised at the engagement for his work with The Rles and their predecessor, The Regiment, over the past six decades. Assistant Colonel Commandant Major General Tom Copinger-Symes will salute and thank him for the support he has given to the Rles and The Regiment since . The Buglers will later sound The Rles Regimental Call and The Advance to conclude the ceremony.The Duke of Edinburgh officially stepped down as a full-time working royal in August  when he was , carrying out his last royal duty in the backyard of Buckingham Palace. In total, he had completed , solo engagements since . The Prince has rarely been seen in public since his final appearance, although he continues to attend Royal Family events.Last week, he attended the secret wedding of Princess Beatrice and Edoardo Mapelli Mozzi with the Queen, maintaining a safe two-metre distance from other guests throughout.Prince Philip has been Colonel-in-Chief of The Rles since it was formed in , but served as Colonel-in-Chief of successive Regiments which have made up The Rles since . title: china uighur slaves coronavirus face masks camps
story: Some companies in China are using a government-sponsored programme that experts claims often puts people to work against their will in order to meet demand for PPE.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesUighurs, mainly from the Xinjiang region of northwest China, are a largely Muslim ethnic minority.The programme sends Uighurs, along with other ethnic minorities, into factory and service jobs.Only four companies in Xinjiang produced medical grade protective equipment before the pandemic, according to China’s National Medical Products Administration.But as of June , that number had increased to .At least  of those companies were found to be participating in the labour transfer programme, according to the New York Times.The companies mainly produce equipment for domestic use but the paper identied several other companies outside Xinjiang that use Uighur labour and export around the world.The Times traced a shipment of coronavirus face masks to a medical supply company in Georgia, US, from a factory in China’s Hubei Province, where more than  Uighur workers had been sent.Workers there are required to learn Mandarin and pledge loyalty to China during weekly flag-raising ceremonies.The Chinese state says the programme is a form of poverty reduction.The Human Rights Investigations Lab at the University of Calornia, Berkeley and the Uyghur Human Rights Project have both collected videos and social media reports that claim to document the recent labour transfers.China has claimed a tight control over Xinjiang is needed to fight what it describes as religious extremism.A spokesman for the Chinese Embassy in the US told the paper the programme helps “local residents rise above poverty through employment and lead fulfilling lives.”But quotas on the number of workers put into the labour programme, along with the penalties imposed on those who refuse to co-operate mean that participation is often, in effect, involuntary.Amy K. title: bbc peter crouch save our summer
story: So distracting you might have missed her ability to ask the killer question.“So, how have you been coping without the football this summer, Peter ”HOW How’d you think, Maya  Like Gemma Collins without the Dunkin’ Donuts’ double down deal, is the combination that first springs to mind.But it possibly underestimates the void at the heart of Peter Crouch: Save Our Summer, a series which must have looked like an easy three-pointer about six months ago.It was Euro  plus “Crouchy”, who is everything a footballer’s not meant to be. Quick-witted, smart, self-deprecating, incredibly likeable and a bit odd-looking. A man who gives hope to fans, both through his career and marriage to Abbey Clancy.Then a double calamity struck. Euro  was cancelled and instead of ­canning the project the BBC pressed on with SOS, shackling it with a hostage-to-fortune title and all sorts of baggage and “other stuff” the show could have done ­without as well.Aside from a garden centre set and enormous table, around which Churchill could’ve signed the Yalta agreement, the baggage came in human form: Crouchy’s former team-mates, The Horne Section studio band, a guest comedian and, of course, Maya, who provided my series highlight when she got dangerously side-tracked by the host’s leisure and tourism qualication.“I don’t want to sound silly or anything,” said Maya, carefully setting her own trap, “But what is a GVNQ ”“It’s a GNVQ.” Obviously.As awkwardly as hosts and guests have all gelled, though, the thing that’s really torpedoed this show has been the other stuff. Those outside broadcasts and studio features that were meant to fill the ­football gap, but didn’t.Two regulars were a chino-clad irritant called Fast Dad, who competed against the host to win football memorabilia for a viewer and “Peter’s Extreme Retirement”, which included all the ideas Alan ­Partridge would’ve thought a bit naff, like water-skiing with Joe Cole.The game not even Crouchy’s GNVQ could help him understand, though, was a VAR-related pun called Very Accurate Rhythm.On Saturday it involved Mo Gilligan playing keepie-uppie to The Horne ­Section’s version of Hit Me Baby One More Time. In previous weeks, however, it was Tinie Tempah and Katherine Ryan having a go at swingball and Jimmy Carr playing Mel C at table tennis.There’s a scoreboard as well, yet no sense of what the hell’s going on here, other than the fact that not a single ­person at the BBC knows how to produce light entertainment.If they did, one of them would have given Peter Crouch the two words of prime-time advice he desperately needed to hear. Don’t. Swear.They didn’t, though. Crouchy and his mates swore like he was presenting a late-night E show and so ended up with an E-sized audience of about one ­million. That’s the reason you never see masters of the light entertainment art, Ant  Dec, dropping the F-bomb.In its youth-driven madness, the BBC might think this is a good thing but it alienates the people who actually pay their wages and has direct consequences for Crouch who, before this started, I thought, could have become a ­Saturday night staple. Now  Mystery guest round on A Question Of Sport, tops. That’s how he’s been coping without the football, Maya.And ex-Celtic manager John Barnes enlivening ITV’s Stephen Lawrence: Has Britain Changed  debate by telling the audience it needed to “elevate people like me and people like Barack Obama”, asthe former US President had ever worked with anyone of the magnitude of Jackie McNamara and Regi Blinker.You’re far too modest, John.Celebrity Snoop Dogs, Kevin McCloud: “It’s the much-loved Martine McCutcheon.” The One Show, Amol Rajan: “Today’s first guest is a man of many talents, Nick Knowles.”Peter Crouch: Save Our Summer, Maya Jama to the host: “God loves a trier.”Loves  He’s sent down a plague of locusts for less than SOS.ANYONE who watched last night’s episode of the landmark BBC series Once Upon A Time In Iraq is unlikely to forget it in a hurry.The story of the  invasion is grimly familiar, but what sets this show apart are the testimonies from its eyewitnesses.None of them wastes words. All of them are mesmerising.Two, though, still managed to stand out from the others.The first was a darkly funny Iraqi called Waleed Nesy who, before he became a journalist’s translator, was pro-war and fronted Baghdad’s only state-approved heavy metal band which, I’m desperately hoping, were called Black Sabba’ath.The other was ferociously bright US army officer Lieutenant-Colonel Nate Sassaman, “a charismatic leader of men” who was hoping to bring peace, democracy and lots of other empty promises to the country until he entered his first local medical centre and: “I’m telling you, the woman running it  She was as hard as a woodpecker’s lips.”Both were damaged by the catastrophe that unfolded and, in the case of Sassaman, helped cause, but they somehow retained their humanity, honesty and sense of humour, which made their testimony all the more astonishing.Like all great war documentaries, Once Upon A Time In Iraq was also prepared to let silence tell the story when the brutality or stupidity became too overwhelming.They made an exception for Waleed, though, when, six weeks into the invasion, President George W Bush boldly declared: “Mission accomplished.”“Mission accomplished  Oh yeah  . . . SERIOUSLY ”Three more episodes will tell you very graphically how well that worked out and they’re as good as anything you’ve watched all year.INCIDENTALLY, I’m grateful to This Morning hosts Ruth Langsford and Eamonn Holmes for revealing blind Celebrity MasterChef contestant Amar Lat measured liquids with “talking jugs”.Which, by a million-to-one coincidence, was also ITV’s original working title for Loose Women.My Strange Addiction: “Eating mattresses can lead to liver damage, intestinal blockage and even death.”But on the plus side, it won’t leave you bed-ridden.Emile Heskey: “When your back’s against the wall, it’s easy to lie down.”Jeff Stelling: “This game will be over when the referee blows the final whistle.”And Chris Kamara: “Three points is another point on the board.”BY the way,you haven’t ever seen Chernobyl, one of the greatest TV dramas ever made, Friday, pm, Sky Atlantic, is your chance.No further excuses will be accepted.WITH no little air of self-congratulation, last week, Celebrity MasterChef welcomed its first ever blind contestant, “travel presenter” Amar Lat, who arrived with a helper and his own super power.“I’ve started to hear the food talking to me,” he explained. “It’s almost like it’s communicating to me and it’s saying . . .”“Don’t worry, Amar. The BBC won’t chuck you out first. It’d look bad.”As good fortune would have it, he didn’t need to worry too much as it was the worst line-up of the series and included Gethin Jones, playing to the camera, rapper Lady Leshurr, whose speciality seemed to be “in-flight meals” and Alan Partridge star Felicity “Lynn Benfield” Montagu, who served up a salad for the guest judges that looked like a Haitian voodoo rattle.The real fall guy, though, appeared to be Jeff Brazier who, at the first challenge, was tugging away at a string of garlic for a good ten seconds before he twigged. “Ah. It’s a decoration. It’s made of polystyrene.”Those people who cry at absolutely everything, of course, were quick to let everyone  know Amar’s eventual progression to the semi-final made them “cry”.I thought the highlight of the week, however, came at the end of the pair’s dessert challenge when the judges’ comments led Amar to ask: “Are you two fat ” and Gregg Wallace replied: “Are you familiar with Jean-Claude Van Damme ”“Yes.”Then get someone to talk you through his voiceover on Minions: The Rise Of Gru.The resemblance is uncanny.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: royal marines new strike force royal navy
story: The new commando unit will have “game-changing technology and weaponry”, the Navy pledged today.It is due to deploy next year as part of an overhaul of the -year-old force.In future Royal Marines will operate in smaller, hi-tech groups – more like Special Forces.These crack commando units will be based on ships at sea, to keep our enemies off balance.Commandant General Royal Marines, Major General Matt Holmes, said: “The Vanguard Strike Company will lead and inform how the Royal Marines and army commandos will operate and fight in a dynamic, technological era of warfare.”The new Vanguard Strike Company will be made of  commandos from the army and marines, who all wear the famous green berets.“We envisage several of these networked sub-units persistently forward deployed around the globe, with an array of sophisticated enabling capabilities, to present dilemmas to adversaries whilst supporting partners. These will all be at high-readiness, as a capable forward contingency force at the core of the Royal Navy,” Maj Gen Holmes added.The Royal Marines’ new role will be closer to the spirit of the original commando raids, launched on Churchill’s orders in World War Two.“This is about ing commando forces to their roots: to operate at reach and in all theatres, including the arctic, as the spearhead of operations,” the Navy said.Hitler ordered all commandos to be shot on site.“The elite commandos will work in small, versatile teams that will be tailored for the respective mission they will be facing – calling on areas of expertise and hone skills necessary to bring an advantage depending on the type of operation,” the Navy added.Typical missions could include send raiding parties ashore from ships to destroy onshore missile batteries and radar systems.Royal Marines and Paras, the elite airborne infantry, have both been named as targets of potential cuts in an upcoming defence review.Neither group had been used to its full capability in recent years. title: coronavirus vaccine christmas uk scientists
story: Early trials of an Oxford University vaccine called ChAdOx show it is safe and triggers a strong immune response.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesAnd a new anti-viral drug may cut the risk of death or serious illness in Covid patients by  per cent. Health Secretary Matt Hancock said our scientists “played a blinder.”The data from research involving more than , healthy volunteers shows a vaccine developed at Oxford University is safe and triggers a strong immune response.Professor Jonathan Van-Tam, England’s Deputy Chief Medical Officer, said the trial result announcement was a “great day for British science.”He is now increasingly hopeful a vaccine will be available “this side of Christmas.”Kate Bingham, of the UK’s Vaccine Taskforce, added: “Optimistically, we’ll be vaccinating by the end of the year.”Professor Adrian Hill, director of Oxford’s Jenner Institute for Vaccine Research at Oxford University, said the results were at the “high end” of expectations.He added: “Its possible for a vaccine being used by the end of the year.”That breakthrough came as it was announced that a “game-changing” drug developed by a firm in Southampton could drastically cut the death rate among Covid- patients.Trials with  hospital patients found the inhaled drug, which uses an anti-viral protein called interferon beta, cut the need for intensive care treatment by  per cent.Patients were also twice as likely to recover during the two-week treatment period.Health Secretary Matt Hancock told MPs the virus is now “on the back foot.”He thanked UK scientists for their efforts and added: “They have played a blinder.”  Further trials of the Oxford vaccine will now begin and officials want half a million volunteers to sign up to help.The vaccine, called ChAdOx nCoV-, is a weakened version of a common cold virus that infects chimpanzees.Scientists modied it with genetic material from Covid-.It works by getting the body to make a protein found on the surface of the bug and priming the immune system against it.Trial data showed volunteers made antibodies and T-cells, a type of white blood cell at the heart of the human immune system, to fight off coronavirus.The effect stayed strong almost two months after vaccination.Professor Andrew Pollard, of the Oxford Vaccine Group, said: “We are seeing good immune responses — exactly the sort of response we were hoping for.”Scientists will now seek to prove the title: douglas murray world wakes up china menace
story: In the s it was the nuclear catastrophe at Chernobyl that revealed to the world the truth about Soviet communism.Not that it was cruel — the world knew that.Not that it was a dictatorship — the world knew that, too.What the Chernobyl meltdown showed was that the cruel Soviet dictatorship was also inept.So it is in recent months with China and the virus that came from the city of Wuhan.The world already knew all it needed to know about China and the Communist Party which runs that country.We knew it was a one-party dictatorship. We knew it cracked down on all domestic opposition. We knew of the way in which they were undercutting the economies of the West.But not until the spread of the Wuhan virus did so many people come to realise how untrustworthy the Chinese leadership is.Now, every day brings more bad news about China. It isn’t because China is doing any-thing new. It is because China has caught the world’s attention.Not in a good way.Just consider the events of recent days.The Chinese government’s mistreatment of its Uighur population in the province of Xinjiang has been known about for years.The Muslim minority group, who regard themselves as closer to Central Asian countries — their language is related to Turkish — have long been in the government’s sights.Armed guardsFor years the Chinese Communist Party has had Xinjiang under its version of special measures.Claiming the one-time independent state, which borders eight countries, constitutes a special security risk, the communists have had the people there under mass surveillance.Even before the recent mass imprisonment, they have had them subjected to forced labour.In recent years they have subjected the entire population to compulsory birth control to try to reduce the size of the population.But for years the world’s attention was not focused on this.We all had troubles of our own to look to.So the Chinese authorities got away with putting perhaps as many as one million Uighur people in what are basically concentration camps — places where these people are meant to be “re-educated” and otherwise “corrected”.Now, drone footage has surfaced which shows shackled, blindfolded prisoners in the province being marched on to trains by rows of armed guards.The scenes are awful.As our Foreign Secretary, Dominic Raab, rightly said at the weekend, they are “reminiscent of something we have not seen for a very long time”.He is right.Yet when the Chinese Ambassador to our country was asked about this at the weekend, he pretended to have no idea what the footage was.He even tried to ert attention by asking his inter- viewer whether he had ever himself been to the charming province in question.But we are not as easily distracted by China as we used to be. Every day brings fresh causes.First, we had China’s appalling behaviour in Hong Kong, breaking its agreements with the UK and cracking down on the local population.Then last week came our Government’s decision to remove Chinese firm Huawei from any involvement in Britain’s G network.Huawei is basically a Chinese government agency and it would have been a serious security breach to allow it to control all our internet communications. Or to develop a back door for looking into them.Then a number of senior Conservatives warned that social media app TikTok is “as much of a threat” to Britain as Huawei.That may sound funny to parents whose children are addicted to it.For most of us, the app is just a source of amusement or bemusement.Depending on your age.But whatever your reaction to it, a growing number of people believe Chinese tech-nologies like TikTok are not safe. Because TikTok’s parent company is ByteDance, a Chinese firm founded in .Of course, the company claims to be independent, as all such firms do, but in China major firms are not independent as they are in Britain or other free societies.Critics insist TikTok could easily be used by hostile forces to harvest information from, and otherwise target, all those who use it.Of course, all of this has brought a degree of sabre-rattling from Beijing.China’s leaders have got used to telling everyone  what to do.As they spread their financial wings in recent decades, countries like ours were very keen to enjoy the benefits.Universities in the UK repeatedly took money from China. Money with strings attached.But money that some of our greedier universities thought was free. Only later learning otherwise.Naturally, the turnaround of recent months has been badly received in Beijing.Its ambassadors and state media have spent recent days pretending it is Britain that is the untrustworthy partner.They are wrong.We are not inconsistent or unfair. We are simply a country that has begun to wake up to a threat.Like the rest of the world. And not a moment too soon.Jaguar Land Rover builds cars for them under a joint venture with Chery Automobile. Pharmaceutical giant AstraZeneca has , employees in China across several manufacturing sites, as well as an innovation centre and a ­campus.So as tensions ramp up after the decision to remove Huawei from the UK’s G network, Britain should remember it, too, has aces to play. Most notably tech and skills.To learn about these is why so many Chinese students come to our universities. It is the same reason why state-owned China General Nuclear Power is a one-third partner in the new nuclear power station at Hinkley Point C in Somerset.It will have a front-row seat to the latest tech as China prepares to build around  reactors of its own.Saying no to Chinese firms is not to be taken lightly.There are around , Chinese companies that do business in the UK. The largest  employ , people.But let’s not forget they need us too.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: NewsopinionDarren Lewis: Forget your ‘civil liberties’, get real and wear a maskWhy would you not want to help protect your friends or your family from the risk of infection, asks Mirror columnist Darren LewisShareByDarren Lewis:,  JUL Updated:,  JUL NewsopinionA masked protester in central London today " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get our daily coronavirus email newsletter with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailIt was the suited guy in the top hat and beak who did it for me. As dozens of the disgusted gathered in Hyde Park to protest the new law to make masks in shops compulsory from Friday, common sense remained as elusive as Prince Andrew. Why would you not want to help protect your friends or your family from the risk of infectionthere is even a scintilla of a chance that you might have the virus  In what world would you view a decree to wear a mask as an infringement on your civil liberties first and a bid to save your le second  If I wear one, I protect you and vice versa. It’s that simple. Oh, and by the way, removing your mask from your face to speak kind of defeats the purpose of the mask. I can copeyou sound a bit muffled. Coronavirus has wrecked families and killed , people worldwide at the time of writing.  Seeing families and pensioners huddling together on Sunday to hear Millennials urging them not to be more safe than sorry was just madness. Your heart went out to the babies with no choice as their indignant parents – many of whom probably clapped for the NHS – jabbed fingers in the faces of anyone daring to disagree with them. Downing Street with its mixed messages clearly doesn’t know it’s Article  from its elbow on the issue. Last week, Michael Gove and Liz Truss were pictured leaving the same Pret A Manger in Westminster – Truss with a mask on and Gove without. Two weeks ago, Gove said face coverings would not be mandatory in shops. Last week, Health Secretary Matt Hancock announced we must all wear them by law, with a £ fine – enforceable by police – for dissenters. This week when asked about wearing a mask in Pret A Manger, Education Secretary Gavin Williamson told Sky News: “It is encouraged though it isn’t officially [sic] that you’ve absolutely got to.”

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe UK’s relations with China hit ­crisis point as Dominic Raab warned on Monday we will not “buck and bow” to the sabre-rattling ­communist state. The Foreign Secretary joined MPs in condemning Beijing’s alleged persecution of Uighur Muslims – appearing to compare it with the Holocaust. He slapped an arms embargo on Hong Kong. He also suspended our extradition treaty with the former British colony over a new security law imposed by China as it continues its crackdown on  pro-democracy protesters. The heightened tensions came after China accused the West of sparking a new “cold war” and threatened “a response” – singling out the UK for freezing tech firm Huawei out of our G network. Saying he was braced for retaliation over Hong Kong, Mr Raab said: “We are absolutely clear, we will not – certainly in relation to Hong Kong but also more generally – we will not buck and bow. “We will look for the positive but we will prepare for the resilience of our economy, our security and indeed the resilience of our values.” Mr Raab and Prime Minister Boris Johnson will today meet US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo, who flew in last night. Collapsing relations with China are expected to top the agenda. MPs yesterday rounded on Beijing in an hour-long debate, highlighting the plight of the Uighur minority in China’s north-western Xinjiang region. Ambassador to the UK Liu Xiaoming denies reports Uighur women are being sterilised to cut the population. On TV this week, he was confronted with footage appearing to show blindfolded Uighurs being marched to trains. It is also claimed authorities are selling Uighur hair on the internet.  Tory MP Neil O’Brien told the Commons: “Whether it’s pictures of Uighur children separated from parents or the horrying footage of Uighurs in chains herded off the trains and into camps, or news the Chinese government is selling the hair of Uighurs, many things are reminiscent of the darkest moments of th century history. “The only way to stand up to a regime becoming more and more bullying is to confront them now.” Mr Raab – whose Jewish father fled the Nazis and whose great-grandparents were murdered in the Holocaust – added that there were “harrowing echoes of what we have seen in the past”. The Foreign Secretary confirmed we will shelve extradition arrangements with Hong Kong in a “reasonable and proportionate” response to China’s new national security law. It gives mainland authorities “the ability to assume jurisdiction over certain cases and try those cases in mainland courts”. An arms embargo on China since ’s Tiananmen Square massacre will also be extended to Hong Kong as a result of the new law. Mr Raab told MPs: “There will be no exports of potentially lethal weapons. It will also ban equipment which might be used for internal repression, such as shackles and smoke grenades.” The UK previously said holders of British Nationalpassports in Hong Kong will get extended rights to join a path to citizenship. More details will be set out this week. The deepening crisis comes just five years after then Prime Minister David Cameron hailed a “golden era” of UK-Chinese relations. In addition to cutting Huawei out of our G network, there are calls for Chinese firms to be blocked from developing nuclear power stations here. Mr Xiaoming said this week: “People say China is becoming very aggressive. That’s totally wrong.  “It’s Western countries, headed by United States, they started this... new Cold War on China.” He also accused Britain of “dancing to America’s tune” with the U-turn on Huawei. But Tory backbencher Bob Seely, on the Commons Foreign Affairs Committee, said yesterday: “The China we hoped for is not now the China we are getting. “And not only in Hong Kong but in foreign lobbying, foreign investment, espionage – industrial or otherwise – and human rights. A much more signicant reset in our relationship is needed.” Labour stepped up calls for “Magnitsky” sanctions on senior Chinese figures – which can include travel bans and asset freezes. Shadow Foreign Secretary Lisa Nandy said: “The suspension of extradition is welcome and will offer much-needed assurance to the Hong Kong diaspora and pro-democracy activists most at risk from new national security legislation.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailHopes were growing a Covid- vaccine could be ready by Christmas after promising trial results. Experts at Oxford found a jab they are developing sparks an immune reaction. Researcher Professor Adrian Hill said: “It’s possible there’ll be a vaccine in use by the end of the year.” With a safe and effective vaccine the only way out of the coronavirus crisis, the promising results from a major trial will be a boost to a nation worn down by the pandemic. Scientists were last night optimistic a jab would be available in six months in the fight against a disease that has killed hundreds of thousands of people and is crippling the economy. And they are hopeful it could be rolled out to NHS and care workers, as well as those deemed high risk, possibly before Christmas. Boris Johnson urged a note of caution by warning the jab may not “come riding over the hill like the cavalry” just yet. But Dr Sandy Douglas, one of the trial’s leaders, said: “I think the vaccine may be available for some people in high risk groups in the UK by the end of the year. It won’t be made available to ­everybody immediately. “It is likely to be given to those who have most to benefit from it earliest, and then gradually introduced to others.” Professor Hill, director of the Jenner Institute at Oxford, added: “It’s possible there’ll be a vaccine being used by the end of the year. But of course it has to work. Evenit worked by early November, you might have emergency use authorisation in a month and be deploying in December. So it’s possible but we can’t guarantee it. “That depends on ­incidence of the disease.” As the UK coronavirus death toll rose by  to , yesterday, the study’s lead author Prof Andrew Pollard said the findings were a “really important ­milestone”. But with large-scale clinical trials still to take place it is too soon to confirm whether the vaccine offers enough protection from the deadly disease. There are also questions over whether it will work in older adults whose immune systemsless well than those of the young. With phase one trials complete, the next rounds will take place in the UK, Brazil and South Africa to confirm whether it works effectively.  Prof Pollard said: “We just don’t know what level is neededyou meet this virus in the wild, to provide protection, so we need to do the clinical trials and to work that out.” His colleague Professor Sarah Gilbert added: “There is still much work to be done before we can confirmour vaccine will help manage the Covid- pandemic, but these early results hold promise.” Health Secretary Matt Hancock said British health officials and scientists had “played a blinder” in their vaccine work. But he told MPs the injection would not be approved until the authorities were “clinically confident” it was safe. Mr Johnson said he “had his fingers crossed” and was “hopeful” the vaccine would be available soon. But the PM added: “To say I’m % confident that we’ll get it this year, or indeed next year, that is, alas, an ­exaggeration. We are not there yet. “If you talk to the scientists, they think the sheer weight of ­international effort is going to produce something. “They are confident that we’ll get some sorts of treatments, some sorts of vaccines, that really make a ­dference. But right now can I tell you that I’m % confident  No.” Oxford’s findings, published in the Lancet medical journal, reveal the vaccine could provide double ­protection against Covid-. In the study, , participants made white blood cells, T-cells, that can fight the disease, within  days and ­antibodies – to stop it coming back – within  days. The early stage of the trial found the vaccine is safe and causes few side effects. Some suffered fever or headache that could easily be treated with pain killers.  No suggested a vaccine would not be compulsory, despite reports that one in four Brits would refuse to have the jab. But the PM’s official spokesman said: “The UK has one of the toughest regulatory regimes in the world anda vaccine is licensed for use then it will be safe for people.” An ideal vaccine against Covid- would be effective after one or two jabs, work in high risk populations and protect for a minimum of six months. The UK has already ordered  million doses of another jab being developed with drugs giant ­AstraZeneca. Chief executive Pascal Soriot said ­mass-production would begin before it was approved so it could then be distributed quickly. He added: “Our hope is that we can start delivering the vaccine before the end of the year, and how early depends really on infection rates in the ­community. We will be able to deliver results in September, but it may take another month or two.”

The PM promised he wonapost make knee-jerk anti-Chinese policy - but todayaposs action is a far cry from the golden era pledged under David Cameron. Hereaposs what has been announced today and how it fits into the wider picture of chilling relations across the world.What has the UK announced today Foreign Secretary Dominic Raab announced the UK will suspend its extradition treaty with Hong Kong, “immediately and indefinitely”.It means someone in the UK whoaposs suspected of a crime in Hong Kong will no longer be handed over to Hong Kongaposs authorities - and vice versa. It follows the example of the US, Canada and Australia. Itaposs happened because of Chinaaposs new national security law - which allows the country to try Hong Kong cases in courts on the mainland. Extradition wonapost resume unless and until there are clear and robust safeguards to stop UK extradition being misused by China. What  has the UK announced   It comes after the UK took a string of major actions against China over Hong Kong, Chinaaposs national security law, and wider concerns over security. The UK was already introducing a new route for Hong Kongers with British nationalstatus - aposBNOapos - to live and work in the UK, and apply for citizenship. While , people currently hold BNO passports, the huge change potentially extends the right to move to Britain permanently to nearly three million people. The “bespoke route” for people from Hong Kong to come to the UK will be ready by , with more details to be confirmed this week. Today UK also revealed it will extend a -year-old arms embargo that applies to the Chinese mainland to Hong Kong as well. He said: “This will mean there will be no exports from the UK to Hong Kong of potentially lethal weapons, their components or ammunition. “It will also mean a ban on the export of any equipment not already banned that might be used for internal oppression, such as shackles, intercept equipment, firearms, and smoke grenades.” Meanwhile, of course, Boris Johnson last week ordered Huawei equipment to be removed from Britainaposs G network by  - amid fears the Chinese state could use the technology to spy on UK citizens. What is Britainaposs link to Hong Kong   Hong Kong island was ceded to Britain after Chinaaposs defeat in the First Opium War in the th century. China leased the New Territories, which forms Hong Kongaposs rural areas, to Britain for  years in . The approaching expiration led to the Sino-British Joint Declaration, signed in , in which Britain agreed toHong Kong to China in . It became a Special Administrative Region of China run under the one country, two systems principle. Hong Kong was to have its own government and legislature composed of Hong Kong people, while its capitalist system, currency and financial markets were to remain intact. What has happened since   Critics have long accused China of eroding Hong Kongaposs special status. Pro-democracy protesters took to the streets of Hong Kong last year in response to Beijingaposs tightening grip on the territory. But Hong Kongaposs legislature has now passed a controversial, Beijing-backed national security law. It makes activities deemed subversive or secessionist punishable by imprisonment, and is seen as targeting anti-government demonstrators. The dramatic blaze that spread across the clfs on Bournemouthaposs seafront was caused by a cooking accident, the fire service has said. The fire, on West Underclf, affected three beach huts and spread over around  metres of heath on the clf face on Monday afternoon. Dorset  Wiltshire Fire and Rescue Service was called at .pm and it took multiple crews and a helicopter to bring the blaze under control. Beachgoers were filmed fleeing the scene as the fire spread quickly up the clf. A spokeswoman said it was understood the fire started in the beach hut when a camping stove was knocked over. Firefighters who tackled the blaze said earlier three huts had been damaged. In clips taken at the beach today, the flames and smoke can be seen to be emanating from the line of beach huts on the promenade at the the bottom of the clf. According to the Mail Online the blaze began on a gas stove at one of the huts, and man was seen rushing out of one of the timber cabins shouting at people to get back as he feared the canister inside could explode.Beachgoers said they heard popping sounds as they sped away from the hut. Le guards ushered beach goers away from the fire before the firefighters arrived at the scene. story: NewsNot all supermarket staff must wear face masks despite new law - rule explainedOn July  legislation requiring the public to cover their noses and mouths when in shops will come into action, but people working in supermarkets will not be required to wear coveringsShareCommentsByHope Woolston:,  JUL Updated:,  JUL NewsStaff will not be required to wear face coverings " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get our daily coronavirus email newsletter with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailSupermarket staff will not need to wear face coverings when a new law comes into force on Friday. On July  legislation requiring the public to cover their noses and mouths when in shops will come into action.Unless they have been specically exempted, anyone caught breaking the rules will face a £ fine, Essex Live reported.Those who donapost have to worry about covering are supermarket staff - despite people shopping in their stores having to wear one. Environment Secretary George Eustice has suggested that it will not be mandatory for staff in places like Asda, Tesco, Sainsburyaposs and Lidl to wear coverings. Speaking on BBC Breakfast last week, he said: We want to give people time to plan and prepare and for retailers to maybe put in place measures to encourage people to do this or potentially even to have some masks themselvespeople haven’t got one. Once you make something mandatory as we’re doing now for retail environments it sends a much stronger signal that people will follow in greater numbers. Speaking about supermarket staff he said: They’re not being covered by this but I thinkyou go into most shops you will see that staff for a longer time now have either been wearing face shields or face masks. It won’t be a compulsory requirement because it won’t always be right for every setting in a retail environment, particularly those working behind the tills and so on.  Many supermarkets have provided coverings for their staff to wear. The majority have decided to wear them, despite it not being mandatory to do so.Last week, Health Secretary Matt Hancock told MPs that they needed to protect shop workers, who have a higher coronavirus death rate than the general public.One way of doing this, he said, was to introduce face coverings.  He said: In recent weeks we’ve reopened retail and footfall is rising. We want to give people more confidence to shop safely and enhance protections for those who work in shops. Both of these can be done by the use of face coverings.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailPrince Andrewaposs team was initially happy with his disastrous Newsnight interview, presenter Emily Maitlis has revealed. The BBC interviewer has said that the palace were shocked, not by the interview but by the public reaction afterwards. The interview, widely described as a “car crash”, saw Andrew speak atabout his association with the convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein. He declined to say he regretted the friendship, with his memorable answers including details of his visit to Pizza Express, saying he was medically unable to sweat and his description of a “straightforward shooting party”. Shortly afterwards the Duke stepped back from royal duties. Prince Andrew has vehemently denied any accusations of wrongdoing over his links to Epstein, including allegations he had sex with Virginia Giuffre when she was  years old. Speaking ahead of the Baftas, where the interview is nominated in the news category, Maitlis told the Radio Times: “We know that the Palace was happy with the interview. We had plenty of engagement with them after it went out. I think their shock was not at the interview itself, but the reaction it caused in the days and weeks afterwards.”  The Newsnight host said she only realised the signicance of her interview with the Duke of York after watching the footage. The Andrew interview won scoop of the year at the Royal Television Society Awards while the BBCaposs flagship current affairs show was also named daily news programme of the year. Maitlis said the penny dropped about the importance of the interview in the editing suite with her programmeaposs editor, Esme Wren.  She said: Weaposd assumed that heaposd want to show empathy to the victims or pin the blame on Jeffrey Epstein. We couldnapost understand why he hadnapost done that. We definitely thought heaposd be spikier... The interview had been a year in the planning and Maitlis said they could have opted for a shorter interview but held out for something more comprehensive. She said within a few minutes of the interview beginning, she knew they had something explosive, adding: First, he was tackling the subject matter head on. Secondly, the lack of apology or any real expression of regret told me that the prince still believed that his actions had broadly been the right ones. And thirdly, the level of detail was unlike anything I was expecting.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailBritish commandos are forming a new “strike company” to spearhead UK military missions against ruthless terror groups and state enemies. The handpicked fighting force is testing deadly new weapons, kit and tactics in readiness for emergency combat missions spearheading battles as soon as next year. Around  Royal Marines – part of the Royal Navyaposs maritime assault force plus a select group of Army commandos - will make up the special-forces style unit. Green Beret “strike” troops are being lined up to perform raiding party-style missions to “soften up” enemy forces before regular Army troops form the main attack. The Royal Marines “Vanguard Strike Company” is being set up to destroy enemy defence lines, lookout posts, airfields and headquarters – often launching from the sea. Dubbed Littoral Strikes – meaning attacks along the coastline – the new commando missions will work closely with special forces units from the elite SAS and SBS. The initial trial unit will grow into a much larger fighting force once tactics and training have been completed – just like the UK commando units did in the Second World War. Once the larger force is set up many of them will be sent abroad, to be put on high alert to be deployed into battle at a few hours notice, massively extending the UKaposs military presence globally.One of the targets would be Russian forces making incursions into Baltic allies of the West or regions like Norway. Where UK commandos train every year as part of their arctic warfare missions and Islamic State globally Defence bosses agreed the new strike force could be set up as part of the Royal Marinesapos massive overhaul – their biggest since Wold War Two. They have been given new, light-weight but hard wearing unorms that dry quickly and Diemaco C- assault rles, proven in battle in Afghanistan. Commandant General Royal Marines Major General Matt Holmes, DSO, who led  Commando in Helmand Province, Afghanistan, in  and a Marine for over  years, said: The Vanguard Strike Company will lead and inform how the Royal Marines and Army Commandos will operate and fight in a dynamic, technological era of warfare. “We envisage several of these networked sub-units persistently forward deployed around the globe with an array of sophisticated enabling capabilities, to present dilemmas to adversaries whilst supporting partners. “These will be at high-readiness as a capable forward contingency force at the core of the Royal Navyaposs Littoral Response Groups.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailWearing a face mask could help beat coronavirus by exposing people to milder forms of the killer bug and so leading to community-level immunity, a new study claims. Face masks have been widely heralded for preventing other people getting infected by blocking the coughs and sneezes of those wearing them. But now scientists also believe they make the symptoms of those who do get the infection less severe by reducing the amount of virus droplets they are exposed to. The paper, by infectious disease experts from the University of Calornia, presents evidence to suggest that masks cut down on the amount of viral droplets getting into the airways. And therefore result in higher rates of asymptomatic or milder infection. A lower initial dose of Sars-Cov-, in theory, gives the immune system a better chance of fighting the bug without the risk of getting severely ill - allowing for a greater chance of immunity while a vaccine is developed. For updates on coronavirus, follow our live blog HERE.  Exposing society to SARS-Cov- without the consequences of severe illness with public masking could lead to greater community-level immunity and slower spread as we await a vaccine, the report states. Face coverings are to be mandatory in England in shops and supermarkets from July , and have been on public transport since June. The paper is due to be published in the Journal of Internal Medicine.  Co-author Monica Gandhi, associate ision chief of the infectious diseases programme at San Francisco General Hospital told the Times said masks lead to a lower dose of the virus. You will get in a lower dose of virusyou wear a mask and are exposed to Covid- and are very likely to have mild or no symptoms. She said the government should go towards universal population-level masking, as a result, including in all workplaces. Other scientists argue masks simply give a  sense of security and believe there hasnapost been enough trialling to prove otherwise.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailFace masks and face coverings are becoming an important tool in the fight against COVID-. Coronavirus is thought to predominantly spread through droplets released from the mouth and nose when coughing, sneezing or speaking.These can be inhaled by another person, or picked upyou touch a surface and then your face without washing your hands first. When used correctly, face masks can contain droplets and stop them from spreading. They are largely designed to stop people from transmitting coronavirus - and are not intended to help the wearer. This means your mask protects other people, while their masks protect you. Where do you legally need to wear a face covering  In England, it is currently only compulsory to wear a face covering while you are using public transport. Anyone travelling by bus, train, plane or ferry is legally required to wear a face covering to protect themselves - and their fellow passengers - for the entirety of their journey. Some people are exempt:Children under  People with breathing dficulties People with any disability that makes it dficult for them to wear or remove a face covering Those travelling with or assisting somebody who relies on lip reading to communicateFace masks can be briefly removed for eating and drinking, to take medication, orinstructed by a police officer or other authority.  From Friday  July it will also become compulsory to wear a face mask in shops and supermarkets. Anyone who refuses can be fined £ by the police, while shops have the right to deny entry to anybody not complying with the rules. The government will publish the law on Thursday  July - just a day before it comes into effect. This will lay out the legal definition of shop, and clary whether businesses such as takeaway sandwich shops are included. Where  do you need to wear a face mask  While there is no legal requirement, it is recommended that you wear a face mask in any confined spaces where it is dficult to social distance.

title: dundee dairy firm expands to include deliveries of oat milk
story: A Dundee entrepreneur is launching an eco-friendly and dairy-free milk option this week # with dairy intolerance an issue close to home.Connor Airlie may be only  but in the past six months he has launched two companies – Dundee Dairy Co and The Oaty Co – with a focus on recyclable and sustainable milk delivery.The Oaty Co will this week start deliveries of oat milk which has been locally sourced and comes in a % recyclable glass bottle which the company claims is the first time a product of its type has come to Scotland.With the aim of serving vegans and those with dairy intolerance, Connor said they already have customers lined up.“When I set up the Dundee Dairy Co we had a lot of people who came to us askingwe delivered any dairy alternatives,” he said.“It is also close to my heart as I have quite a few family members who are dairy intolerant.“I thought I definitely wanted to do something to supply the demand but it took a while to find a local supplier who could make it for us.“We are also incredibly passionate about being % recyclable on all of our products. vw, px"  “I would watch David Attenborough’s programmes and saw the masses of plastic waste and landfills filled with it.“I just kept seeing that image in my head and knew there must be something I could do to make a dference.”The Oaty Co will be starting deliveries of its products from Wednesday with free delivery around Dundee and surrounding areas.Connor, who was formerly employed as deck crew offshore, said that while it has been daunting starting the businesses he has had a massive amount of support and help from family. He added: “It was a big change for me from working offshore to starting my own businesses.“I have received an incredible amount of help and support from my family members as well as my partner Michaela who co-owns the business. title: dundee united lawrence shankland goals premiership
story: Dundee United striker Lawrence Shankland says he can’t wait to prove he is Premiership class.The Scotland international, , was the Championship’s top scorer last season as the Tangerines sealed promotion to the top flight.He scored  goals in  appearances for club and country in  .Speaking to Sky Sports at the launch of United’s new home kit, the former Ayr man said: “Every time I’ve come up against a Premiership team with a Championship club I’ve scored.“So I know I can score against teams at that level.“I’m excited to go up and accept the challenge. title: dundee united micky mellon calum woodger squad
story: It’s a player’s dream for a new manager to come in and say they’ll all get a chance to prove themselves, so credit goes to Micky Mellon for doing just that at Dundee United.However, with two weeks until the new Premiership season starts and no new first-team recruits in the door, United fans would be forgiven for feeling a little anxious.Besides the addition of young reserve goalkeeper Jack Newman it’s been all quiet in terms of ins and outs at Tannadice as new boss Mellon assesses his squad.Not even a fortnight in the hot seat himself, he is well within his rights to do just that.He needs to have an informed opinion of what he has at his disposal and where he may need to strengthen.That comes from seeing players up close and in the flesh, watching them in sessions and in games but also getting to know them as people.These are all important steps for a new regime to get maximum results.I fear, though, by leaving it too late the Tangerines could get off to sticky start on the pitch under Mellon.Don’t get me wrong, there is a lot of talent in that Terrors pool as it stands.In Lawrence Shankland you have a prolic marksman and potential star in the making for club and country.Liam Smith, Jamie Robson, Nicky Clark and Paul McMullan will be itching to show what they can do at the highest level.Americans Dillon Powers and Ian Harkes provide good options and there’s young talent like Louis Appere, Declan Glass and Logan Chalmers, too.That’s not to mention experienced campaigners like Benjamin Siegrist, Mark Connolly, Mark Reynolds and Calum Butcher, who United have relied on for the last  months.They have all stepped up to the plate and handled that responsibility to earn United their spot at the top table and deserve the chance to defend it.However, going into the Premiership for the first time in four years, I still feel United are a little thin on the ground.Quality is, of course, more important than quantity and I’m sure Mellon will have his targets that he feels can add something to the club. In terms of pure squad size, though, cover is needed.We’ve already seen with Siegrist, Butcher and Shankland struggling with injury how short the Terrors could be in crucial early games.A couple of extra bodies would alleviate any concerns of stling.That all but one of their under-contract first-team players accepted a wage cut is cause for optimism for Dundee.The vast majority of the squad making a salary sacrice is testament not only to the players as iniduals but to the togetherness of the club as well.It should reassure Dark Blues supporters they’ll be just fine on the pitch next season under James McPake.He’s clearly built a solid team spirit and bond – one strong enough to see them through the trials and tribulations on and off the park in the months ahead.However, the fact Kane Hemmings is the exception to the rule and could, potentially, be out the door at Dens Park is the last thing the Dee would’ve wanted.Minus the English striker, Dundee are a dferent animal. He, after all, was their marquee signing last summer.The hitman is more than just a goal-scorer, he’s their talisman. Iniably,the -year-old performs well then so do his team.Finding a replacement of his quality would be some task but Dee fans should be hoping all is not lost on No  sticking around.As a proud Scotsman it pains me to say it but Harry Kane truly is a magnicent goal-scorer.He has done it consistently for seasons now butthere was ever any doubt about his ability he has well and truly quashed that by netting his th club career goal against Newcastle on Wednesday.At just ,he stays fit, you wouldn’t bet against him topping Alan Shearer’s Premier League record and Wayne Rooney’s England total.That the Premiership is due toin two weeks and we still have arguments raging between the SFA, SPFL and its member clubs is, sadly, no surprise.Surely this should have been sorted amicably by now PODCAST: Twa Teams, One Street – Does Kane Hemmings have a future at Dundee and will Benjamin Siegrist be fit for United’s opener " title"#PODCAST: Twa Teams, One Street – Does Kane Hemmings have a future at Dundee and will Benjamin Siegrist be fit for United’s opener # # Evening " src"https:www.eveningtelegraph fp podcast-twa-teams-one-street- embed # secretJqBekuS" data-secret"JqBekuS" width"" "" frameborder"" marginwidth"" margin"" scrolling"no"For as little as £. a month you can access all of our content, including Premium articles.Newsletter Get top stories straight to your inbox every day.SUBSCRIBE HERE!Latest blaize_config   n t t tCancelation Offer % - Web + ePaperGet unlimited access to the Eveningwebsite and Premium Content and all the benefits of the print paper in a digital replica of the Evening  n t t t t n t t t ua. per month  u recurring subscription n n t t t n t t t tEdition: n t t t tWeb + ePaper n t t t n t t t n t tSubscribe TodayEnjoy the digital edition of the Eveningnewspaper on your smartphone, tablet and computer.Unlimited access to all articles on the Eveningwebsite. title: mark connolly ireland ambitions dundee united premiership return
story: Dundee United defender Mark Connolly hopes Premiership football boosts his chances of pulling on the green of Ireland once more.Connolly has represented his country through the age group levels, winning seven U  caps but has never made a full international bow.With top-flight football at United just around the corner, he is hoping Irish gaffer Stephen Kenny has more opportunities to sit up and takes notice of his performances next season.The -year-old centre-back, from Clones, admits it would be ‘huge’ for him to win his first cap and is relishing the chance to prove himself at the highest level.“I have always had the ambition to play for my country, %,” the former Crawley Town and Kilmarnock man said.“Playing down in England can be dficult and some boys will concede that but when you play up in Scotland in the Premiership you have that aim.“The world watches you and the Scottish leagues are very good, especially the Premiership.“I played there with Kilmarnock and I really enjoyed it, although I had a few injuries in that spell.“If I got the chance to break back into the international scene at full level it would be huge for me.”However, Connolly insists his initial focus is on performing well for the Tangerines in the Premiership when the new term kicks off next month.The Terrors will play their first top-tier fixture in four years on August  when St Johnstone come to Tannadice for the Tayside derby.With that match just over two weeks away, Connolly is greatly anticipating the challenge ahead for the club.He continued: “Playing back in the Premiership will also be big for me!“I came back up to Dundee United because I knew that was the aim and to get there now is magnicent.“There is no reason why I can’t aim for thatbut the first aim is to help United establish themselves back into the Premiership.“Whatever happens after that happens.”Of his international ambitions, Connolly revealed some household names he grew up with on the Irish scene and admits they are men he’d love to line up alongside again.“I played all the way from U  to the U s,” he added.“I played with the likes of Robbie Brady, Jeff Hendrick, Shane Duffy, Enda Stevens, Matt Docherty, James McCarthy and Greg Cunningham.“It is the majority of the full squad.“It is one of those things you want to get back playing there and, hopefully, getting back to the Premiership and I can do well then you never know what could happen.“It is something I would love to happen in the future.”The Terrors have a proud recent history of Irishmen pulling on tangerine and Connolly says it’s an honour to join the likes of legends Sean Dillon and Jon Daly in representing the club.“Sean Dillon, Jon Daly, Noel Hunt and Willo Flood have all played,” he commented.“Dundee United is a great club with a great history and I am sure that when we come back to the Premiership that we will attract even more international players in the future.“United is a huge club in Scotland and I speak for all the players we are all proud to pull on the jersey.”For as little as £. a month you can access all of our content, including Premium articles.Newsletter Get top stories title: st andrews university plans to build almost 750 new student bedrooms
story: St Andrews University is planning to build more affordable student accommodation.The university has submitted a planning application to Fe Council for  new student beds at Albany Park in the town.Albany Park is the centrepiece of a £ million investment by the university in student accommodation over the next few years which will create an additional , new bedrooms.It is hoped this will help the university to meet its commitment to reduce its impact on the town, by building purpose-built student accommodation which is operated and managed by the university itself.Currently, the university provides , student bedrooms.It is also hoped the proposed development, half of which will be classed as affordable accommodation, will help ease the pressure on the housing market in St Andrews.Ben Stuart, director of residential and business services at the university, said: “The development at Albany Park is central to the university’s strategy to provide more student accommodation for our students and ease the pressure on the housing stock in St Andrews.“The new Albany Park will provide around  high quality student beds in an attractive landscaped environment and has the potential to revitalise the eastern area of St Andrews.”This application comes after an initial proposal was submitted to the local authority back in October.Following this first application, the £m development was reviewed and the proposed number of beds was cut from  to  after concerns were raised over flood risks.The developers have also altered the scale, height and mass of the buildings, including dropping by one floor on some.However the near % cut in bed numbers means there is now more space for landscaping on the site and to bring back Woodburn Square, which was a feature of the area for hundreds of years.There have also been some changes to the design of the proposed development in a bid to make the building more reflective of St Andrews’ historic architecture.Planning
